Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Influence of Low-Carbon Energy Technology Scientists and Engineers on the Composition of Energy Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Overview

This project is a collaborative, multi-sited ethnographic study that will examine how the rhetoric used by scientists serves to influence scientific contributions to policy.

Intellectual Merit

The researchers will examine how scientists engage and argue with one another about policy. Specifically, they will collect and analyze the rhetoric used by scientists who are engaged in the development of two types of low carbon energy technologies, wind power and nuclear power, in order to understand how the composition of their reasoning influences energy policy, and how their rhetoric could serve as a productive starting point for integrating scientific knowledge into policy decisions.

Broader Impacts

The project has societal relevance in terms of training a diverse set of students in social science methodologies and of making the participating scientists aware of the results so as to improve the integration of science in policymaking with respect to the crucial issues of climate change mitigation and energy security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Influence of Low-Carbon Energy Technology Scientists and Engineers on the Composition of Energy Policyis a collaborative research project conducted by Dr. Danielle Endres (University of Utah) and Dr. Tarla Rai Peterson (University of Texas, El Paso). 

Due to global changes, scientific innovation, and current policies, energy production and consumption is one of the most pressing issues facing both the United States and the world. Low-carbon energy technologies (LCET)?such as nuclear power, wind and solar energy, and carbon sequestration?are closely related to both scientific innovation and hot button issues in societal deliberation that significantly impact the potential for implementation of these technologies. The future of energy must be treated as both a technical and social issue. This project represents one way of examining the socio-technical opportunities and constraints in the development of energy technologies. 

This project examined how low-carbon energy technology (LCET) scientists talk among themselves about the socio-technical facets of energy technologies. The PIs examined how LCET scientists in nuclear, wind, solar, and carbon sequestration technologies used both technical and prudential (social and value-based) forms of reasoning in their rhetoric about the socio-technical significance and feasibility of these technologies. This form of internal rhetoric of scientists was accessed through participatory fieldwork methods including observation and interviews with scientists at LCET conferences. PIs Endres and Peterson postulated that LCET scientists would use forms of socio-technical rhetoric based on blended forms of technical and prudential reasoning in scientist-to-scientist conversations at these conferences. The findings offer a better understanding of how scientists combine technical and prudential forms of reasoning to produce socio-technical rhetoric about the future of energy technologies. Ultimately, this project has increased knowledge abouthow scientists: 1) blend technical and prudential modes of reasoning; and 2) break down boundaries between science and society within their professional and purportedly ?technical? rhetoric. 

This project accomplished a number of goals. First, the project facilitated the collection and analysis of LCET scientist internal rhetoric, creating an empirical data set that can be used to better understand how LCET scientists and engineers talk among themselves about scientific and societal aspects of energy technologies. Second, the project examined Bruno Latour?s composition metaphor as a theoretical framework for analyzing the composition of blended technical and prudential forms of reasoning by LCET scientists. Third, the project contributed knowledge to several areas of ongoing research (see intellectual merit). Finally, the project disseminated findings through academic publications. Thus far, Dr. Endres? research team published 2 journal articles, four book chapters, and seventeen conference or symposium presentations. Two of the book chapters and one of the conference presentations received awards from the National Communication Association. 

The primary intellectual meritof the project is forging a new line of research in rhetoric of science (RoS) that highlights how the internal rhetoric of scientists uses blended forms of technical and prudential reasoning. This project expands on several current areas of research. First, much previous RoS and science communication research focuses on cases in which scientists communicate about scientific and technical research to non-scientist publics. This project uniquely examined how scientists and engineers talk about the relationship between science and society in internal scientist-to-scientist rhetoric. Second, previous RoS research suggeststhat scientists and engineers primarily use only technocratic forms of reasoning when talking with other scientists and employ only prudential forms of reasoning when interacting with non-scientist publics. Building from research in science, technology, and society (STS) that revealed the close interconnections between science and society within the practices of scientific communities, this project contributes to RoS by providing empirical examples of scientists using both technical and prudential reasoning in their internal rhetoric. Third, previous RoS research has traditionally relied primarily on textual analysis. Expanding on Dr. Endres? methodological expertise in rhetorical fieldwork?the combination of textual analysis with ethnographic fieldwork?this project builds a methodological approach that can be used to access forms of scientific rhetoric that have not traditionally been analyzed by rhetorical scholars. Finally, this project contributes to STS research with a focus on the importance of the specific communication and rhetorical practices of scientists and engineers in making claims about the interconnection of science and society. 

The broader impacts of the project includeincreasing knowledge about the types of arguments that are used in the development and dissemination of LCETs for climate change mitigation, economic development, and energy security. These insights may enable stakeholders to better understand the multi-faceted roles that the rhetoric of scientists play in energy decision-making.More specifically, the project: 1) disseminated of the results of this research to both academic and scientific audiences through publications (see: https://www.danielleendres.com/nsf); 2) broadened participation of women and underrepresented groups through the graduate students and undergraduate students recruited to participated in the research; and 3) incorporated results into ongoing programs of teaching.
